title: Rifle inventory records (Lassen County Sheriff's Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Rifle inventory records (Lassen County Sheriff's Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Records of the most recent inventory of rifles possessed by the Sheriff's Office, as defined in Sections 30510 and 30515 of the Penal Code (assault rifles, patrol rifles, sniper rifles, .50 caliber rifles).
2. Records indicating the number of rifles, as defined in Sections 30510 and 30515 of the Penal Code,  privately possessed by personnel of the Sheriff's Office with its authorization, OR the number of Sheriff's Office personnel with such authorization.

To assist with the prompt release of responsive material, I ask that you make records available to me as you locate them, rather than waiting until all responsive records have been collected and copied.
 
The requested documents or information from them will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

If you would like to discuss these requests, please feel free to reach out to me, John Lindsay-Poland, co-director of the American Friends Service Committee California Healing Justice Program at jlindsay-poland@afsc.org or by phone at 510-282-8983.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

John Lindsay-Poland

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: Rifle inventory records (Lassen County Sheriff's Department)
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Nasise,

Thank you so much for your response to my Public Records Act request #1, regarding rifles owned by the Lassen County Sheriff's Office. 

Your letter did not address #2 of my request, for "Records indicating the number of rifles, as defined in Sections 30510 and 30515 of the Penal Code, privately possessed by personnel of the Sheriff's Office with its authorization, OR the number of Sheriff's Office personnel with such authorization."

Could you please let me know whether a search was conducted for records of such privately possessed rifles of Sheriff's Office staff and/or authorization of such possession.

Thank you.

best,
John Lindsay-Poland

communications.subject: Vermont Public Records Act Request: VT mDL Program Records (Jan 2023–Present)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Vermont Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Planning documents, feasibility studies, pilot proposals, implementation roadmaps, and any vendor marketing materials or brochures provided to the agency, as well as internal deliberations about whether or how to move forward with an mDL program, created between January 1, 2023 and the present.

Agreements, contracts, or memoranda of understanding with vendors or partners, including but not limited to AAMVA, IDEMIA, Thales, GET Group, Apple, Google, Samsung, or other providers.

Interagency or interstate coordination documents, including but not limited to MOUs or correspondence with AAMVA or other states regarding mDL interoperability or standards development.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rebecca Williams

communications.subject: City Records Request :: N000429-081025
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
RE: City Records Request of August 10, 2025, Reference # N000429-081025 Dear Robbie Powelson, The City of Novato received a public records request from you on August 10, 2025. Your request asked for: 

All email communications between City Council Members Mark Milberg, Rachael Farac, Tim O'Conner, Kevin Jacobs, and Pat Eklund and Brian Skinner between January 1 2025 and August 11 2025. 

All email communications between City Council Members Mark Milberg, Rachael Farac, Tim O'Conner, Kevin Jacobs, and Pat Eklund that includes the words "Skate Park" "Homeless" and "tent" "unhoused" 
The City has determined that it is in possession of records that are responsive to your request and we anticipated that the responsive, non-exempt records will be provided to you within 30 days from the date of this letter. By furnishing you this initial response, the City does not waive any of its rights to claim or invoke any exemptions or other grounds for withholding any records located during its research and review which it determines to be responsive to any request but not required to be disclosed under the California Public Records Act. The City intends to provide its grounds for withholding any records at the completion of the review and disclosure process.  If you have any concerns or questions, do not hesitate to contact me by replying to this email. Kindest regards, Laura McDowall 
City Clerk

communications.subject: City Records Request :: N000429-081025
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
RE: City Records Request of August 10, 2025, Reference # N000429-081025 Dear Robbie Powelson, This is in response to your Public Records Act Request and follows the City's communications of August 10, 2025, August 20, 2025,  September 9, 2025 and September 10, 2025. The City of Novato received your California Public Records Act request, dated August 10, 2025, which requested the following: All email communications between City Council Members Mark Milberg, Rachael Farac, Tim O'Conner, Kevin Jacobs, and Pat Eklund and Brian Skinner between January 1 2025 and August 11 2025. 

All email communications between City Council Members Mark Milberg, Rachael Farac, Tim O'Conner, Kevin Jacobs, and Pat Eklund that includes the words "Skate Park" "Homeless" and "tent" "unhoused" 
Under Government Code section 7922.535, subdivision (a), this message shall serve as a formal response to your request. This message shall also serve as notification that I am the person responsible for determining which records are responsive and subject to production under Government Code section 7922.540. 

The City has completed a reasonable search of its records and determined there are responsive documents as well as certain records and/or portions thereof which have been determined to be exempt from disclosure and have therefore been redacted or will not be disclosed pursuant to the statutory exemptions noted below: 

 
  *  Attorney-Client Privilege – Government Code sections 7927.705 and 7930.110; Evidence Code sections 952 and 954; Bus. & Prof. Code section 6068 – Records which are exempted or prohibited pursuant to federal or state law, including those relating to attorney-client privilege, are exempt from disclosure.  
 
  *  Attorney Work Product – Government Code sections 7927.705 and 7930.110; Code of Civ. Proc. section 2018.030 – Writings that reflects an attorney’s impressions, conclusions, opinions, or legal research or theories are exempt from disclosure.  
 
  *  Deliberative Process Privilege – Government Code section 7922.000; Times Mirror Co. v. Superior Court (1991) 53 Cal.3d 1325; California First Amendment Coalition v. Superior Court (1998) 67 Cal.App.4th 159 – The public interest in nondisclosure clearly outweighs the public interest in disclosure of records revealing the deliberations of agency officials used to reach a decision because of the potential chilling effect disclosure would have on candid, informed policymaking.  
 
  *  Preliminary Drafts and Similar Materials – Government Code section 7927.500 – Any preliminary drafts, notes, or interagency or intra-agency memoranda that are not retained by a public agency in the ordinary course of business are exempt from disclosure where the public interest in non-disclosure is clearly outweighed by the public interest in disclosure. The public interest in nondisclosure clearly outweighs the public interest in disclosure of records revealing incomplete planning and deliberation between inter and intra agency officials used to reach a decision because of the potential chilling effect disclosure would have on candid, informed policymaking and regional collaboration on sensitive issues.  
 
  *  Personally Identifying Information – Government Code section 7922.000; American Civil Liberties Union Foundation v. Superior Court (2017) 221 Cal.Rptr.3d 832 – The public interest in nondisclosure clearly outweighs the public interest in disclosure of information that infringes upon privacy rights, such as personal cell phone numbers and e-mail addresses.  
 
  *  Confidential Informants and Investigatory or Security Files  – Government Code sections 7923.600, 7922.000; Evidence Code sections 1040, 1041 – Any complaints to a local police agency or any investigatory or security files compiled by a local agency for correctional, law enforcement, or licensing purposes are exempt from disclosure. The public interest in nondisclosure clearly outweighs the public interest in disclosure of the identity of a person who has furnished information in confidence to the City for administration or enforcement of a law alleged to be violated.  
 Public Interest Balancing Test – Government Code section 7922.000 – The public interest in nondisclosure clearly outweighs the public interest in disclosure of records that would reveal inter and intra agency deliberative processes and drafts, personal contact information, the identities of individual complainants, or would otherwise impede the City’s ability to coordinate public responses or policy decisions. The responsive records are available using the following link: 
City Records Request - N000429-081025 (https://u8387778.ct.sendgrid.net/ls/click?upn=u001.VEsWrlMiJDg0mXafq1mEXbzH6-2Fd5sE2jVnwq9X8NPpyh-2Fqcjpx2s7sp8fUo2KPo3tDnu-2BQ9OUcE-2FwEJM0j3rY7cCgqbpWkt-2B4tn0VcFC2fE-3DiVOY_9CbA04xfgwfwb2ZTHMNJme4rDMzosohjD-2BMKdPzseaxT0onxwfoKrHzEDPUdg8tbiU9Gggebz95AZk7nQ6v8OM9jWBfHk4TJveJn09-2BoTvMymKZPYSA9c99NaEBBFrTfdhVxC4H6Tb-2BEBF7SLLQJ-2FlQuGLl9otu56f-2FTwUS0S7suHZib7ehNGliUgQYEP89noipYw7zsJ-2BBdrWSUs9frh-2B5QiUoI3oAI61zBXfMSPULnay4mBR2aFFwKUUgE7wZxMqHKKaE-2BMOHIBkWu5dPhr9F4Vn0QLg52oXaOYxGN48gg8u7vXC2fBoBftKtJO5cXpESCU8RRJtzMt56j7eXiqzLJhgBmqAqcAAy9SoJyeB-2BO9nje5HkeY303Z4p-2FVBSW) Please be advised the City will not allow inspection or copying of any privileged documents. While we will try to remove all privileged documents, the inadvertent inclusion of any privileged documents does not constitute a waiver and we ask you to notify us of any privileged material that is inadvertently provided. Also be advised the City is not required to produce documents that are exempt from disclosure under the California Public Records Act, records destroyed in accordance with Government Code section 34090 and the City’s records retention policy, or records that include such information that the public interest served by not disclosing the records clearly outweighs the public interest served by the disclosure of the records. 

Please let me know if you would like to discuss your request further or if I can assist you in clarifying the request, identifying records responsive to the request, or requesting additional records. 

Kindest regards, 

Laura McDowall 
City Clerk

I am writing to make a simple track request of all documents pertaining to Jeffrey Epstein's Zorro ranch that have already been released to KRQE, as documented by the Article below.

 https://www.krqe.com/news/new-mexico/krqe-news-obtains-documents-from-new-mexico-attorney-generals-epstein-investigation/

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Daniel Boguslaw

communications.subject: Your New Mexico Department of Justice public records request #25-375 has been submitted.
communications.communication:
New Mexico Department of Justice ************************************************************************ Your record request #25-375 has been submitted successfully. This is an automated message. Thank you for submitting your request to the New Mexico Department of Justice. We will review your request and begin processing it. Typically, you will receive two communications from us, one within three business days and the second within 15 days. If we need additional time to process your request, we will let you know in our 15 day communication. If you have any documents relevant to your records request, please upload them or provide copies to us to assist with our searches. Please also let us know if you are looking for an exact document within our records so that we may provide it to you more quickly. We strive to complete requests as timely and completely as we can and your assistance will help us in this process. If you need to contact us, you may reply to this message. ************************************************************************ Reply to this email or sign in to contact New Mexico Department of Justice.

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: ALPR Data Sharing (Coronado Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

We request the following records related to Automated License Plate Readers ("ALPRs") and your law enforcement agency ("Agency").

Information related to ALPR data sharing.

1. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares ALPR data;
2. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives ALPR data;
3. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares “hot list” information;
4. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives “hot list” information.

The information requested in items 1-4 is readily available for extraction through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Data Sharing Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality.  

We also note that your agency has provided these records to us in the past. 

We also request that any records maintained in an electronic format be provided in that same format (such as a PDF, CSV or XLS file), to avoid copying costs. However, should you be unable to do so, EFF will reimburse you for the direct costs of copying these records (if you elect to charge for copying) plus postage. If you anticipate that these costs will exceed $25.00, or that the time needed to copy the records will delay their release, please contact me so that I can arrange to inspect the documents or decide which documents I wish to have copied. Please also provide an invoice and a cost breakdown of the fee estimate. If the fees are less than $25.00, please copy and send the records and invoice as soon as possible, and we will promptly pay the required costs.

Thank you for your consideration of this request. If you have any questions or concerns, or if I can provide any clarification that will help identify responsive documents or focus this request, please do not hesitate to contact me at (415) 436-9333 x151 or dm@eff.org. You may also mail correspondence to the Electronic Frontier Foundation, 815 Eddy. St. San Francisco, CA, 94109.
                                               
Sincerely,
 
 Dave Maass
Director of Investigations
Electronic Frontier Foundation

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Dave Maass

title: Interim US Attorney Ed Martin Letters to Georgetown University Law Center

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Interim US Attorney Ed Martin Letters to Georgetown University Law Center
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Any communications between Interim United States Attorney Ed Martin and Georgetown University, Georgetown University Law Center, or William M. Treanor  between February 1, 2025 and May 8, 2025.

"Communications" means and includes emails, text messages, social media messages, letters, memoranda, calendar entries, chats, or any other form of one-to-one or one-to-many communication.

Please note that this request seeks public records wherever they may be found, including on devices or networks owned or operated by private parties. For example, if an employee uses a personal cell phone or social media account to conduct public business, records created, maintained, or held on the phone or account are public records subject to this request.

REQUEST FOR EXPEDITED PROCESSING:

I request that this request be expedited under 28 CFR § 16.5(e)(1)(ii) and (iv) for the following reasons:

1. I certify the following to be true and correct: My organization is primarily engaged in disseminating information. The Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression (FIRE) maintains a news website at https://thefire.org/news, through which its staff members regularly publish news stories and editorial content concerning the activities of governments, government officials, and other persons or organizations of public concern. I am a staff member of FIRE. I frequently write about matters involving the First Amendment and academic freedom, including on FIRE's website. See, e.g., https://www.thefire.org/news-archive?author=303. A substantial component of my duties as a staff member of FIRE is to obtain information through public records requests, including through the Freedom of Information Act, which I or my colleagues then share through FIRE's website and social media channels. I also publish news and other information of public concern via "X" (https://x.com/adamsteinbaugh) and "Bluesky" (https://bsky.app/profile/adamsteinbaugh.bsky.social).

2. The requested information concerns an actual or alleged government activity, namely a United States Attorney's initiation of an "inquiry" into the academic content of courses at a private law school.

3. The requested information extends beyond the public's right to know about government activity generally and instead has a particular value that would be lost if not processed on an expedited basis. The information pertains to a news story of public interest. That issue has attracted a wide range of news media coverage, including the numerous articles identified below, which are helpful in establishing that there is an urgency to inform the public on this topic.

Examples of recent articles demonstrating the public's ongoing and current interest in this information include articles:

a. https://www.washingtonpost.com/dc-md-va/2025/03/05/dc-us-attorney-ed-martin-georgetown-law-dei/
b. https://thepostmillennial.com/us-atty-ed-martin-demands-georgetown-law-school-answer-for-dei-in-curriculum-hiring-and-programs
c. https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/06/us/politics/ed-martin-us-attorney-washington-trump.html
d. https://thehill.com/homenews/education/5181345-georgetown-law-school-dei-trump/
e. https://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow-show/maddowblog/trump-appointed-prosecutor-gets-much-needed-refresher-first-amendment-rcna195321
f. https://www.rawstory.com/ed-martin-georgetown-clash/
g. https://reason.com/volokh/2025/03/07/may-government-refuse-to-hire-notre-dame-students-because-notre-dame-teaches-and-promotes-anti-abortion-ideology
h. https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/mar/06/ed-martin-us-attorney-dei
i. https://www.newsmax.com/politics/georgetown-dei-william-treanor/2025/03/06/id/1201790/
j. https://www.wusa9.com/article/news/politics/federal-fallout/georgetown-law-school-wont-bow-to-dei-threat-from-dcs-acting-federal-prosecutor-ed-martin-donald-trump-william-treanor/65-22ac5a1d-43a8-492b-92db-1f8c6f70f76c
k. https://www.usatoday.com/story/opinion/columnist/2025/03/07/dei-georgetown-us-attorney-first-amendment/81793644007/
l. https://www.washingtonian.com/2025/03/07/william-treanor-georgetown-law-ed-martin-first-amendment/
m. https://abovethelaw.com/2025/03/georgetown-law-to-ed-martin-f-all-the-way-off/
n. https://www.thecollegefix.com/top-d-c-federal-prosecutor-says-he-doesnt-want-law-students-from-georgetown-because-of-dei/
o. https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2025/03/georgetown-william-treanor-ed-martin-trump-doj-dei.html
p. https://www.foxnews.com/media/georgetown-professors-slam-trumps-dei-crackdown-attack-religious-freedom-jesuit-schools

4. This information is relevant to a matter of widespread and exceptional media interest in which there exist possible questions about the government's integrity that affect public confidence. There is widespread and exceptional media interest in this matter, as reflected in the above articles originating from outlets across the ideological spectrum. This matter raises "possible questions" about government integrity affecting public confidence because the alleged conduct involves a United States Attorney's pressure on a law school to limit viewpoints offered in classroom teaching protected by the First Amendment. A prominent First Amendment scholar has raised questions about the propriety of Attorney Martin's "inquiry." Eugene Volokh, "May Government Refuse to Hire Notre Dame Students, Because Notre Dame Teaches and Promotes Anti-Abortion Ideology?" (Volokh Conspiracy, March 7, 2025), https://reason.com/volokh/2025/03/07/may-government-refuse-to-hire-notre-dame-students-because-notre-dame-teaches-and-promotes-anti-abortion-ideology. Further, Attorney Martin's letter was sent as members of the United States Senate requested disciplinary action against Attorney Martin due to his similar efforts to suppress speech protected by the First Amendment. See https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/06/us/politics/ed-martin-us-attorney-washington-trump.html. 

REQUEST FOR A FEE WAIVER OR REDUCED FEES:

I request, under 28 CFR § 16.10(k), a waiver or reduction of fees for the following reasons:

1. Disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest because its disclosure would shed light on the operations or activities of the government. The requested information pertains specifically to controversial conduct by an Interim United States Attorney.

2. Disclosure of the requested information would be likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of those operations or activities. Disclosure of the requested information would meaningfully inform the public about the Department's activities and operations.

3. Disclosure of the requested information will contribute to the understanding of a reasonably broad audience of persons interested in the subject, as opposed to the individual understanding of the requester. The requestor is a licensed attorney who practices First Amendment law. As such, the requestor will be able to effectively convey information to the public. Further, the requestor is a representative of the news media. The requestor and his employer, the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression, gather information of potential interest to a segment of the public, turns that information into distinct works (including through its news website, located at https://thefire.org/news), and distributes that information to the public. The information requested here relates to information that is about current events or that would be of current interest to the public. The requestor's past publication record (in addition to FIRE's articles available at https://thefire.org/news) is available at https://www.thefire.org/news-archive?author=303.

4. The requested information is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester. The requestor works for a nonprofit organization and the records are not sought for a commercial purpose.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

On Dec. 15, 2023:
Subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: MVIPC Calls (Department of Homeland Security Office of Inspector General)
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any document listing all referrals, calls, or complaints involving allegations arising at the Moshannon Valley ICE Processing Center beginning June 1, 2021, and continuing through December 15, 2023.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

On Dec. 15, 2023:
Subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: MVIPC Calls (Department of Homeland Security Office of Inspector General)
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any document listing all referrals, calls, or complaints involving allegations arising at the Moshannon Valley ICE Processing Center beginning June 1, 2021, and continuing through December 15, 2023.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

title: $10,000,000  HUD Grant to AIDS Healthcare Foundation for Tenant Education Outreach Program under Blueprint for Renters

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: $10,000,000  HUD Grant to AIDS Healthcare Foundation for Tenant Education Outreach Program under Blueprint for Renters
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1-All  communications, applications, certifications, and representations of the AIDS Healthcare Foundation ("AHF") in obtaining a $10,000,00 grant for HUD's Tenant Education Outreach Program ("TEO").
2. All terms of any agreement that AHF must follow in order to obtain this grant.
3. All terms of any agreement that AHF must in distribution of grant money.
4. Any terms of commitment that AHF signed and/or agreed to, in providing decent, safe, sanitary, healthy, housing for tenants, and/or in providing tenants rights advocates access to the distribution of tenants' rights information. 
5. Any emails between HUD and AHF concerning the TEO program.
6. All disclosures made from AHF concerning or relating to any of the lawsuits against AHF including but not limited to any of the following lawsuits:
•	AIDS Healthcare Foundation v. Karla Leiva, LASC Case No. 22STRO00633, which was in front of Commissioner Laura Cohen who granted the tenant's rights advocate's Anti-SLAPP motion. Ms. Leiva was a tenants’ rights advocate and AHF filed a temporary restraining order against Ms. Leiva, prohibiting her from coming onto AHF properties. Subsequently, Judge Michael R. Powell entered judgment in favor of the tenants' rights advocate on AHF’s remaining claim that our client threw feces at an AHF employee. AHF was ordered to pay the tenants' rights advocate more than $44,000 in attorneys’ fees.
•	Tammy Davis v. AIDS Healthcare Foundation, LASC Case No. 20STCV08627, which was in front of Judge Daniel Buckley (Ret.) and now Judge William Highberger. This ongoing case concerns the Madison Hotel’s uninhabitable living conditions. The class has been certified and consists of approximately 350 tenants. This is the case that recently settled this past weekend for $575,000 to tenants, plus nonmonetary relief. Plus AHF's cross-complaint against the City of Los Angeles which was dismissed on the City's Motion for Summary Judgment.
•	Carlos Brum v. AIDS Healthcare Foundation, LASC Case No. 23STCV07822, in front of Judge Kenneth Freeman. This ongoing putative class action case concerning the Baltimore Hotel’s uninhabitable living conditions.
•	Alisha Lucero v. AIDS Healthcare Foundation, et al., LASC Case No. 19STCV28098. This matter has been resolved, and was in front of Judge Dennis Landin (Ret.) and then Judge Upinder Kalra. This case concerned AHF’s unlawful eviction of Ms. Lucero and throwing away all of her possessions without notice. 
•	Grace Antisdel, William Berry, Julia Bigboy, Linda Carrasco, Dwane Davis, Michael Davis, Enrique Deliz, Tammy Davis, Rodney Duck, Errol Ennis, Edwin Linwood, Kenneth Montgomery, Darnell Moses, Kenneth Owens, Brenda Phillips, Vance Pitts, and Trimal Williams v. AIDS Healthcare Foundation, LASC Case No. 21STCV04049. This matter has been resolved and was in front of Judge Stephanie Bowick. The publicly known settlement amount is $820,000, and concerned the Madison’s elevator outages and the effect of those outages on tenants with disabilities.  Plus AHF's cross complaint against the City of Los Angeles, for which the City paid AHF $100,000 to resolve that cross-complaint.
•	James Ellis v. AIDS Healthcare Foundation, LASC Case No. 22STCV35702. This matter was recently resolved. The case was in front of Judge Anne Hwang. This case concerned a Madison tenant who had a long history of violent behavior shooting another tenant, James Ellis, and AHF’s failure to evict the violent tenant before the shooting. AHF cross-complained against the County of Los Angeles and the Los Angeles Sheriff’s Department. Judge Hwang sustained the County entities’ demurrer without leave to amend.
•	Annette Turner and Tammy Davis v. AIDS Healthcare Foundation, et al., LASC Case No. 20STCV4667. This case is active and is in front of Judge Robert Broadbelt. This case concerns a sexual assault committed by AHF’s unlicensed and unvetted contractor to do repairs in Ms. Davis’s room. This case is also concerning Ms. Turner’s individual uninhabitability claims in her personal unit due to repeated flooding from the common areas.
•	Pernell Monger v. AIDS Healthcare Foundation, LASC Case No. 23STCV19686. This matter is active and in front of Judge Randolph M. Hammock. This concerns a Madison tenant’s personal claims for disability discrimination, failure to accommodate, bedbugs, roaches, and other uninhabitable conditions.
•	Maria Umana, Douglas Umana Gomez, Sasha Salgado, Ruben Flores, Reina Melchor, and Miguel Valencia v. AIDS Healthcare Foundation et al., LASC Case No. 22STCV00361. This case concerns the lack of habitability of AHF’s Sinclair apartment complex. 
The at least 85 evictions AHF has filed against its tenants. The approximate 80 small claims lawsuits AHF has filed against its tenants.
•	•	Michael Weinstein v. City of Los Angeles et al., LASC Case No. BC210058.
•	Michael Weinstein v. City of Los Angeles et al., LASC Case No. BC214564.
•	Michael Weinstein v. City of Los Angeles et al., LASC Case No. BC140892.
•	AIDS Healthcare Foundation v. City of Los Angeles, LASC Case No. BS161771.
•	AIDS Healthcare Foundation v. City of Los Angeles, LASC Case No. BC717911.
•	AIDS Healthcare Foundation v. City of Los Angeles, LASC Case No. 19STCP00520.
•	AIDS Healthcare Foundation v. City of Los Angeles, LASC Case No. 19STCP03103.
•	AIDS Healthcare Foundation v. City of Los Angeles, LASC Case No. 19STCP04094.
•	AIDS Healthcare Foundation v. City of Los Angeles, LASC Case No. 19STCP04589.
•	AIDS Healthcare Foundation v. City of Los Angeles, LASC Case No. 19STCP04532.
•	AIDS Healthcare Foundation v. City of Los Angeles, LASC Case No. 20STCV29238. (AHF appealed Judge Rupert Byrdsong sustaining of the City’s demurrer without leave to amend. AHF appealed, and the Appellate court affirmed the dismissal.) 
•	AIDS Healthcare Foundation v. City of Los Angeles, LASC Case No. 21STCP00049.
•	AIDS Healthcare Foundation v. City of Los Angeles, LASC Case No. 21STCP04176. (Here, AHF sued the City to prevent the development of affordable housing.)


7. Any discussion or disclosure to HUD, or research conducted by HUD, into AHF's involvement with any of the following issues covered in the below news articles:

•	https://www.latimes.com/homeless-housing/story/2020-03-08/homeless-housing-aids-healthcare-foundation-lawsuit-skid-row-tenants
•	https://www.latimes.com/homeless-housing/story/2023-01-20/ahf-madison-hotel-elevator-lawsuit-story
•	https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2023-02-10/residents-of-a-downtown-hotel-settle-with-aids-healthcare-foundation-over-elevator-failures
•	https://knock-la.com/aids-healthcare-foundation-housing-hazards-1/
•	https://knock-la.com/aids-healthcare-foundation-housing-hazards-2/
•	https://knock-la.com/aids-healthcare-foundation-housing-hazards-3/ 
•	https://www.latimes.com/homeless-housing/story/2024-03-27/aids-healthcare-foundation-acquire-skid-row-housing-trust-portfolio 
•	https://laist.com/news/housing-homelessness/los-angeles-aids-healthcare-foundation-michael-weinstein-madison-hotel-settlement-rent-control-proposition-prop-33

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Annette Morasch

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #24-FI-HQ-03356
communications.communication:
Re: Case No. 24-FI-HQ-03356

What is the status of this request? It has now been over 30 days with nothing but an autoresponse which assigned the FOIA number.
Thank you.

communications.subject: Request Note Notification Email - U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
communications.communication: "We are currently processing your request and will notify you as soon as the search has been completed. If you have any questions, you may contact me at Robin.L.Berry-Crawford@hud.gov. Thank you"

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #24-FI-HQ-03356
communications.communication:
It is well past 30 days and it is apparent a writ of mandate will need to be filed against HUD for its failure to follow the public records act requirements. 

Production of communications on a rolling basis is acceptable, but the actual grant and AHF’s signature agreeing to take certain actions —those must be produced immediately.  There is no excuse for what the contract itself cannot be immediately produced.  This issue has been in the LA Times. So produce the contract immediately in order to prevent a writ of mandate being filed against HUD. 

Thank you so much.

communications.subject: Request Note Notification Email - U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
communications.communication: "I apologize for the delay in the processing of your request. In processing these requests, we are responsible for tasking other program offices for the records. The search for your records is near completion. We will keep you informed as your case progresses. If you have additional questions, you may reach me at Robin.L.Berry-Crawford@hud.gov.  Thank you"

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #24-FI-HQ-03356
communications.communication: I have received your auto-response.  I have called and emailed you personally to learn why it is taking so long to produce an agreement that accompanies handing $10,000,000 to a company.  There is at least an agreement that you can produce now for the public to see. Please produce at least the contract which disburses a significant amount of taxpayer money to an entity that had an injunction entered against it for interfering with tenants’ rights advocates, and is refusing to acknowledge a tenants union.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #24-FI-HQ-03356
communications.communication: Four months with no response. Why isn't HUD complying with the law?

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #24-FI-HQ-03356
communications.communication:
United States Representative Laura Friedman's office has contacted you and you have not returned their communication.
I have contacted you repeatedly.
This is a simple request. Why is the contract not even being produced in the interim of HUD looking into other requests?

communications.subject: Request Note Notification Email - U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
communications.communication: "I am working on your case now. "

communications.subject: Request Note Notification Email - U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
communications.communication: "There was an issue with me messages from PAL. I want to inform you that I am working on your case now. I had to get some clarifications from the program office but that has been done. "

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #24-FI-HQ-03356
communications.communication: Hello, three days ago you stated "I am working on your case now."  And I have not heard anything else.  I am begging you to please just provide the contract and application today and you can roll out the rest of the requested documents later.  It's been five months and you haven't even given me a contract for $10m in federal tax payer money. I fail to see how this is possible.

Click here to log in https://hudpal.efoia-host.com.
Regards, 
U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development

I cannot access the website you have linked.  It is too buggy. I get nothing but error messages. I'm sure your "message" is just yet another delay in producing documents anyway.

Put your response here on Muckrock so it will be public.

Would like to request any and all information related to a police response to the Wellesley neighborhood in Clayton on 9/4/2025 at ~4:05pm

title: Niskayuna Strategic Plan for Equity – May 2021

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Niskayuna Strategic Plan for Equity – May 2021
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

specifically and exclusively related to the creation and development of the document titled:

“Niskayuna Strategic Plan for Equity – May 2021”
Publicly posted at: https://www.niskayunaschools.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Niskayuna-Equity-Infographic-May-2021.pdf
Archived copy: https://web.archive.org/web/20240810034840/https://www.niskayunaschools.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Niskayuna-Equity-Infographic-May-2021.pdf

This document was formally presented to the Board of Education on May 25, 2021 and was publicly released via email on May 27, 2021. See Board presentation version here:
https://go.boarddocs.com/ny/nisk/Board.nsf/files/C3CJ4N4AF975/$file/District%20Equity%20Plan%20-5-25-2021.pdf
Archive copy: https://archive.is/hhgW0

This request is strictly limited to records directly related to the creation, development, review, formatting, or publication of the above-linked document. Records that do not specifically relate to this document should be considered nonresponsive.

I request the following records created prior to May 27, 2021:
	1.	All draft versions of the “Strategic Plan for Equity – May 2021” document
	2.	All internal planning documents, notes, and working drafts used by any group that contributed to the document
	3.	All presentation materials (slides, notes, handouts) created to present or explain this document, including those prepared for the May 25, 2021 Board of Education meeting
	4.	All existing records that identify individuals, working groups, or committees who contributed to, reviewed, or participated in the creation of the “Strategic Plan for Equity – May 2021,” including but not limited to meeting agendas, sign-in sheets, planning rosters, participant lists, acknowledgments, or committee documentation
	5.	All contracts, invoices, scopes of work, or deliverables from any consultants or vendors involved in creating, editing, formatting, or supporting the publication of this document
	6.	Any edits, contributions, or review materials from Capital Region BOCES related to this document

Please note:

Under the NYS Archives Retention and Disposition Schedule LGS-1 and applicable federal regulations:

• LGS-1 Item 68 requires that strategic plans and long-range planning documents be retained permanently
• Supporting documentation such as drafts, planning notes, working group records, and preparatory materials must be retained for at least 6 years after the plan is superseded or obsolete
• LGS-1 Item 500 requires that contracts and vendor records (including invoices, scopes of work, and deliverables) be retained for at least 6 years after expiration or completion
• LGS-1 Item 47 requires that Board of Education meeting minutes be retained permanently

In addition, where development of this document involved or was supported by federal funds (e.g., Title I, Title II, ARP ESSER, or other federally subsidized equity or professional development initiatives), the following federal regulations apply:

• 2 CFR § 200.334 (Uniform Guidance) requires that all records related to federal awards, including planning documents, contracts, and supporting materials, be retained for at least 3 years from the date of final expenditure reporting—and longer if litigation, audit, or investigation is ongoing
• 34 CFR § 100.6(c) and related Title VI of the Civil Rights Act provisions require that recipients of federal education funding maintain all records necessary to demonstrate compliance with non-discrimination and equity obligations, including program design, planning, and implementation materials

Together, these retention requirements make clear that the requested records should remain in the district’s custody and available for production under FOIL and federal oversight. Failure to produce these materials may constitute noncompliance with both FOIL and records retention obligations.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jackson Parker

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Niskayuna Strategic Plan for Equity – May 2021
communications.communication:
Subject: FOIL Appeal – Niskayuna Strategic Plan for Equity (May 2021) – Follow-up and Timeline Request

Dear Records Access Officer,

I am writing to appeal your response—or lack thereof—to my New York Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request submitted on July 22, 2025, regarding the “Strategic Plan for Equity – May 2021.” As of September 2, 2025, the district’s response status remains “Awaiting Acknowledgement”:
https://www.muckrock.com/foi/niskayuna-23437/niskayuna-strategic-plan-for-equity-may-2021-189993/

Under Public Officers Law § 89(3)(a), a response—including an acknowledgment or denial—was required within five business days of receipt of the request. The district is well past its statutory timeline.

This appeal is intended to formally request that the district:
- Acknowledge receipt of my FOIL request immediately.
- Provide an estimated timeline for its fulfillment, including anticipated delivery of responsive documents.
- If applicable, identify any non-responsive items and explain the basis for any redactions, exemptions, or fees.

Please note that NYS Archives LGS-1 requires permanent retention of strategic plans and a six-year minimum retention for supporting drafts, notes, and contracting records. Federal regulations (2 CFR § 200.334; 34 CFR § 100.6(c)) also require retention of records tied to federal funds and equity compliance for no less than three years.

For transparency and consistency, I am copying this appeal to the New York State Committee on Open Government (COOG), which has issued public guidance reinforcing the five-day acknowledgment requirement and the timely provision of responsive records.

Thank you for your prompt attention.


CC: NYS Committee on Open Government (COOG)

communications.subject: Re: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Niskayuna Strategic Plan for Equity – May 2021

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Niskayuna Strategic Plan for Equity – May 2021
communications.communication:
Subject: FOIL Appeal – Strategic Plan for Equity (May 2021)

I am writing again regarding my FOIL appeal submitted September 2, 2025 concerning the Strategic Plan for Equity – May 2021. In your response, you stated:

“All requests for information should be directed to our records management officer, Matt Leon. I have copied him on this email so that he may begin to process your request.”

That reply reflects a misunderstanding. As this communication is a statutory appeal under Public Officers Law §89(4)(a)—not an initial request—it is your obligation, as the designated appeals officer, to review and determine the appeal within ten business days, not refer it back to the records access officer.

COOG’s guidance is explicit:

- The FOIL Appeals Officer cannot also serve as the Records Access Officer (see: https://opengovernment.ny.gov/foil-training-materials).
- That officer “must either provide records sought or ‘fully explain’ reasons for further denial (or both) within 10 business days” (ibid).
- The statute requires that the appeal, and the written determination, be transmitted to COOG immediately upon receipt and upon issuance of the determination (ibid).

Your misdirection—sending the appeal back to the records access officer—is contrary to both the statute and COOG’s formal advice. At this point, the absence of a determination constitutes a constructive denial of the appeal. 

I also note a concerning pattern of procedural non-compliance by the district in handling FOIL requests and appeals, reflected in repeated delays and misapplications of the process.

Given that COOG is copied here, I respectfully recommend COOG consider mandating FOIL training and compliance measures for Niskayuna CSD, including clarification of the separation between the Records Access Officer and the Appeals Officer, and reinforcing timeliness obligations.

I again formally request, without further delay:

1. A proper written determination on my appeal, in accordance with §89(4)(a);
2. Confirmation that both the appeal and your determination have been transmitted to COOG as required.

cc: Committee on Open Government

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Niskayuna Strategic Plan for Equity – May 2021
communications.communication:
Subject: FOIL Appeal – Request for Determination (MR #189993)
Thank you for your Sept 4, 2025 letter. Under COOG’s FOIL training, appeals are not remanded to the RAO; the appeals officer must decide the appeal within 10 business days. Please issue a written appeal determination by that deadline that (a) grants, denies, or partially grants each category with specific legal bases; (b) releases all non‑exempt portions immediately with redactions as necessary; and (c) certifies any non‑existence or unsuccessful diligent search under POL §89(3). Please also reconcile the receipt date discrepancy (June 22 vs. MuckRock’s July 22 submission) and confirm a date‑certain for any remaining production. For clarity, key categories are: drafts/working materials for the May 2021 equity plan and 5/25/2021 board slide deck; rosters/acknowledgments of contributors; and any Capital Region BOCES Communications Service contract/SOW/invoices/deliverables used to produce or format the plan/infographic.

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Richard Thomas Martinez Case Footage
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I respectfully request copies of all records in your possession related to the investigation of Richard Thomas Martinez in connection with the death of Bradley Minder (October 2024, Sylvan Drive, Riverside). Specifically, I am requesting body-worn camera footage, crime scene video footage, interrogation recordings or transcripts, crime scene and evidence photographs, incident and investigative reports, dispatch or call audio, and any other investigative materials that can be lawfully disclosed to the public.

Please provide the records in electronic format if possible. If there are fees associated with this request, kindly inform me in advance. If any part of this request is denied, I ask that you provide a written response citing the specific legal basis for the denial.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Mahad Mohammed

RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of September 16, 2025., Reference # W019281-091625. 
Dear Mahad , 
The Public Records Advocate received the below records request from you on September 16, 2025. To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 

I respectfully request copies of all records in your possession related to the investigation of Richard Thomas Martinez in connection with the death of Bradley Minder (October 2024, Sylvan Drive, Riverside). Specifically, I am requesting body-worn camera footage, crime scene video footage, interrogation recordings or transcripts, crime scene and evidence photographs, incident and investigative reports, dispatch or call audio, and any other investigative materials that can be lawfully disclosed to the public. 

Please provide the records in electronic format if possible. If there are fees associated with this request, kindly inform me in advance. If any part of this request is denied, I ask that you provide a written response citing the specific legal basis for the denial. 

The requested information is exempt from public disclosure pursuant to Government Code sections 7923.600–7923.625, as it pertains to information compiled as part of a criminal investigation and is contained in an investigatory record maintained by a law enforcement agency, see Rivero v. Superior Court (1997) 54 Cal.App.4th 1048; New York Times Co. v. Superior Court (1997) 52 Cal.App.4th 97; Williams v. Superior Court (1993) 5 Cal.4th 337; and Haynie v. Superior Court (2001) 26 Cal.4th 1061. 
Please see attached response from the Riverside Police Department for additional information, including non-exempt responsive records. 
If you have any questions, please contact the Riverside Police Department Records Division at (951) 826-5700. 
Sincerely, 
Carmen Soto 
City Clerk’s Office 
(951) 826-5557 CSoto@riversideca.gov (mailto:CSoto@riversideca.gov)

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Student Assignment, OSD
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

In the CPS Procedural Manual, it states, "The IEP team then submits a school assignment request to ODLSS to provide the appropriate school closest to the student’s residence that can implement the IEP."

Provide records sufficient to show the following:

1. A blank form/submission for the school assignment request;
2. Anonymized data of all school assignment requests made on behalf of CPS students with IEPs requiring placement for the 2023-2024, 2024-2025, and 2025-2026 (to date) school years. These records should include a unique non-identifiable code for the student, the date their IEP was finalized, the date the school assignment request was made, the date the school assignment letter was issued, and the date the student enrolled.

This request is made on behalf of The FOIA Bakery. Because this request is in the public interest for Illinois nonprofit The FOIA Bakery’s work to advocate for public education, please waive any fees in accordance with 5 ILCS § 140/6(c). Feel free to contact me with any questions, or if clarification is needed.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Miriam Bhimani

Chicago Public Schools (CPS) responds to all public records requests in accordance with the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq. 
Due to the volume and complexity of requests received in the normal course of business, CPS is extending the time for its initial response to your request by an additional 5 business days (to 10 business days total beginning on the first business day following receipt of the request) pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/3(e)(v) which allows for the examination and evaluation of the requested records by personnel to determine if they are exempt from disclosure under Section 7 of Illinois FOIA or should be revealed only with appropriate deletions. 
Upon the completion of a response, CPS will provide the first 50 pages to you at no charge.  If a response is more than 50 pages, a fee of 15¢ per page will be charged for each additional page. All applicable fees must be paid prior to the copying. CPS will inform you of any fees due if your paper response exceeds 50 pages. You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you’ll receive an email when your request has been completed. Thank you for using the CPS FOIA Center.

09/17/2025 Miriam Bhimani 
Dear Miriam Bhimani: RE: Chicago Public Schools FOIA Request N018136-082525 Thank you for using the Chicago Public Schools FOIA Center. You requested the following: To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records: 

In the CPS Procedural Manual, it states, "The IEP team then submits a school assignment request to ODLSS to provide the appropriate school closest to the student’s residence that can implement the IEP." 

Provide records sufficient to show the following: 

1. A blank form/submission for the school assignment request; 
2. Anonymized data of all school assignment requests made on behalf of CPS students with IEPs requiring placement for the 2023-2024, 2024-2025, and 2025-2026 (to date) school years. These records should include a unique non-identifiable code for the student, the date their IEP was finalized, the date the school assignment request was made, the date the school assignment letter was issued, and the date the student enrolled. 

This request is made on behalf of The FOIA Bakery. Because this request is in the public interest for Illinois nonprofit The FOIA Bakery’s work to advocate for public education, please waive any fees in accordance with 5 ILCS § 140/6(c). Feel free to contact me with any questions, or if clarification is needed. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Miriam Bhimani 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fchicago-public-schools-3121%252Fstudent-assignment-osd-191915%252F%253F&url_auth_token=AAATZySh2wlr8X3Y5z0jngwF9c%3A1uqkuV%3Ay5kW_3bjD6jedYRMoOcU4_TDJB4i1NQ_OLzFLTiUE54 RESPONSE: Documents responsive to your request are available to download via the CPS FOIA Center at www.cps.edu/FOIARequests . Please log in with your username and password to access the records.  Please note that the data provided is raw data and may contain errors and/or omissions. Please also be advised that the District does not comprehensively track the date a student enrolled as a result of a school assignment request . Thus, this portion of your request is asking the District to create a new record to answer your question. The Freedom of Information Act requires a public body to provide existing public records, subject to certain exceptions. The request must reasonably describe the requested records. A reasonable description requires the record to be reasonably identified as a record not as a general request for data, information and statistics to be gleaned generally from documents which have not been created and which the [public body] does not generally create. (See Krohn v. Department of Justice, 628 F.2d 195 (1980)). Second,  FOIA obligations apply to the provision of existing public records; a public body is not required to answer questions or generate new records in response to a FOIA request. Kenyon v. Garrels, 184 Ill. App. 3d 28, 32,    540 N.E.2d 11, 13 (1989) (quoting Krohn v. Department of Justice, 628 F.2d 195, 198 (D.C. Cir. 1980)). This request requires CPS to not merely pull data out of a database and provide it to you, but instead asks CPS to compile data from multiple sources into a single record, manipulate it to answer your questions, and this combination of data does not already exist in any CPS database. (See generally Hites v. Waubonsee Comm. College, Il App 2d, 150836 (2016)(... "requests went beyond a search for records—that is, the data in the databases—and instead improperly sought information about those records." quoting National Security Counselors v. Central Intelligence Agency, 898 F. Supp. 2d 233, 271 (D.D.C. 2012) and Chicago Tribune v. DFPR, IL App. (4th) 130437 at 8 (2014) ("[t]he Department was not obligated ... to answer plaintiff's "general inquiry question" concerning the number of initial claims since this would have required creating a new record.")  
You have a right to have the denial of your request reviewed by the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at the Office of the Illinois Attorney General. 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a). You can file your Request for Review with the PAC by writing to: Leah Bartelt; Public Access Counselor Office of the Attorney General 500 South 2nd Street Springfield, Illinois 62706 E-mail: public.access@ilag.gov 877-299-3642 You also have the right to seek judicial review of your denial by filing a lawsuit in the State circuit court. 5 ILCS 140/11. If you choose to file a Request for Review with the PAC, you must do so within 60 calendar days of the date of this denial letter. 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a). Please note that you must include a copy of your original FOIA request and this denial letter when filing a Request for Review with the PAC. Sincerely, Patricia Majchrowicz Freedom of Information Act Officer Chicago Public Schools

title: Citiguard Vehicle Pursuit at CoreCivic Detention Center in Caliofornia City, CA

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Citiguard Vehicle Pursuit at CoreCivic Detention Center in Caliofornia City, CA
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

This request is for the Bureau of Security and Investigative Services (BSIS) of California. 

Context: A video widely circulated on social media shows two individuals approaching a CoreCivic Detention Center in California City, CA On September 2, 2025. A uniformed security patrol officer in a Citiguard vehicle approached them. The security officer asks them to stop recording and leave property, and then appears to initiate a vehicle pursuit in a Citiguard marked patrol vehicle on public roads that reach reported speeds of 70mph to 100mph. According to BSIS's website, Citiguard's owner is GHARZAI NOMAIR, and Citiguard has two  previous citations for employing non-licensed security officers. 

As such, I am requesting the following:
1) Citiguard's License, Certificates, or other verification documents that indicate their authority to work in California City, CA
2) Citiguard's current Private Patrol Operator application and/or most recent renewal application, packet, or documentation submitted to achieve BSIS licensure for license 121572, and for any branch or other licenses that permit Citiguard's operations within California City, CA. 
3) Any complaints, investigations, notices, or tips related to Citiguard from January 2024 through the date of completion of this request 
4) Any emails that your office has received or sent relating to the September 2nd, 2025 incident involving Citiguard at the CoreCivic Detention Center
5) Any Citiguard policies relating to foot or vehicle pursuits, use of force continuum, verbal de-escalation, or patrol SOPs that are in your possession

This is a newsworthy event, I respectfully request that you expedite this request to the extent possible. You may send documents as they become available. I appreciate you taking the time to fulfil this request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Alan J. Segal

title: ALPR Data Sharing (Hickory Hills Police Department)

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: ALPR Data Sharing (Hickory Hills Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

We request the following records related to Automated License Plate Readers ("ALPRs") and your law enforcement agency ("Agency").

Information related to ALPR data sharing.

1. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares ALPR data;
2. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives ALPR data;
3. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares “hot list” information;
4. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives “hot list” information.

The information requested in items 1-4 is readily available for extraction through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Data Sharing Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality.  

We also note that your agency has provided these records to us in the past. 

We also request that any records maintained in an electronic format be provided in that same format (such as a PDF, CSV or XLS file), to avoid copying costs. However, should you be unable to do so, EFF will reimburse you for the direct costs of copying these records (if you elect to charge for copying) plus postage. If you anticipate that these costs will exceed $25.00, or that the time needed to copy the records will delay their release, please contact me so that I can arrange to inspect the documents or decide which documents I wish to have copied. Please also provide an invoice and a cost breakdown of the fee estimate. If the fees are less than $25.00, please copy and send the records and invoice as soon as possible, and we will promptly pay the required costs.

Thank you for your consideration of this request. If you have any questions or concerns, or if I can provide any clarification that will help identify responsive documents or focus this request, please do not hesitate to contact me at (415) 436-9333 x151 or dm@eff.org. You may also mail correspondence to the Electronic Frontier Foundation, 815 Eddy. St. San Francisco, CA, 94109.
                                               
Sincerely,
 
 Dave Maass
Director of Investigations
Electronic Frontier Foundation

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Dave Maass

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Bamaca-Zacarias Mortality Review
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of the IHSC Mortality Review for Brendy Yohana Bamaca-Zacarais, who died in ICE Custody September 7, 2024, according to the Detainee Death Report ICE published: https://www.ice.gov/doclib/foia/reports/ddrBrendyYohanaBamacaZacarias.pdf

I make this request as a member of the media, and therefore seek a fee waiver. Representative edited works based on prior FOIA requests like this one may be reviewed here: https://theappeal.org/authors/andrew-free/; and here: https://atlpresscollective.com/2025/01/31/new-record-sheds-light-on-unreported-death-in-atlanta-airport-customs-inspection/. 

I request expedited processing of this request pursuant to 6 CFR 5.5(e) and attest under penalty of perjury pursuant to 28 USC 1746 that the following statements are true and correct to the best of my knowledge and understanding: 
1. ICE deaths in custody in FY25 are currently on track to equal or surpass the 12 deaths in the previous fiscal year. 

2. IHSC Mortality Reviews provide an authoritative agency accounting of the medical circumstances of in-custody deaths. These reviews often conflict with the public-facing story the agency tells, raising critical questions about accountability, transparency, waste, fraud, and abuse. See https://phr.org/our-work/resources/deadly-failures-preventable-deaths-in-u-s-immigration-detention/.

3. The current administration's expansion of federal immigration detention is the subject of widespread and exceptional media interest in which there exist possible questions about the government's integrity which affect public confidence. See, e.g., 
a. https://www.newyorker.com/news/the-lede/how-many-immigrants-will-die-in-us-custody
b. https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/politics-and-government/nevada/ice-increases-detention-capacity-in-southern-nevada-3318591/&ct=ga&cd=CAEYAioTODA4NDM3NjM3MDcwNDg3MjU0NDIaMzU4OGE4OGMwMWViNjNlYTpjb206ZW46VVM&usg=AOvVaw0AY_z02AvW4eN7-HW7Pbvr
c. https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/politics-and-government/nevada/ice-increases-detention-capacity-in-southern-nevada-3318591/
d. https://www.leavenworthtimes.com/kansas-politicians-say-an-awful-lot-but-look-beyond-those-words/
e. https://latenighter.com/news/john-oliver-shares-chilling-details-about-ice-detention/
f. https://www.bisnow.com/national/news/capital-markets/private-prison-firms-predict-unprecedented-growth-from-trumps-immigration-crackdown-128291
g. https://www.wkbn.com/news/local-news/youngstown-news/corecivic-trying-to-add-space-for-ice-detainees/
h. https://prismreports.org/2025/01/15/biden-immigration-migrant-deaths/
i. https://prismreports.org/2024/06/25/nearly-all-deaths-in-ice-detention-over-5-years-were-preventable/
j. https://www.kcbd.com/2025/03/11/garza-county-now-reviewing-proposals-interested-giles-w-dalby-correctional-facility-operators/
k. https://capitalandmain.com/more-people-in-ice-custody-means-smaller-meals-and-delayed-medical-care-detainees-say
l. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2025/mar/11/german-tourists-ordeal-reportedly-ending-returned-from-us-detention
m. https://www.denverpost.com/2025/03/11/denver-ice-expand-detention-capacity-colorado-wyoming/
n. https://www.aclufl.org/en/press-releases/three-deaths-ice-custody-just-over-month-trumps-presidency-marks-most-deaths-occur
o. https://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/nation/privately-run-immigration-detention-center-that-previously-held-families-in-texas-will-reopen/
p. https://www.natchezdemocrat.com/2025/03/05/a-city-within-a-city-wardens-at-adams-county-correctional-discuss-benefits-challenges-of-max-occupancy-at-ice-facility/
q. https://www.goodmorningamerica.com/news/live-updates/trump-2nd-term-live-updates-va-prepares-to-cut-as-many-as-72000-employees-in-next-wave-of-layoffs-memo-119377651
r. https://www.washingtonpost.com/immigration/2025/03/05/dilley-texas-family-detention-center-ice/
s. https://finance.yahoo.com/news/corecivic-announces-resumption-operations-south-211500232.html
t. https://www.spokesman.com/stories/2025/mar/04/for-profit-kansas-prison-with-troubled-history-cou/
u. https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2025/03/private-prison-mass-deportation-trump-billions-geogroup-corecivic-ice/
v. https://filtermag.org/trump-deportations-private-prisons/amp/
w. https://www.axios.com/2025/03/06/corecivic-immigrant-family-detention-center-texas
x. https://theappeal.org/mahmoud-khalil-lasalle-detention-center-louisiana/
y. https://law.yale.edu/yls-today/news/students-document-reports-abuse-immigration-detention-center
z. https://www.investigativepost.org/2025/02/20/521935/

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

communications.subject: ICE FOIA 2025-ICFO-25063
communications.communication:
03/17/2025 

Andrew  Free 
MuckRock News, DEPT MR182986 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICFO-25063 
 
Dear Requester: 

This acknowledges receipt of your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), dated 3/13/2025, your request for a waiver of all assessable FOIA fees, and your request for expedited treatment. Your request was received in this office on 3/13/2025. Specifically, you have requested all records pertaining to IHSC Mortality Review for Brendy Yohana Bamaca-Zacarais, who died in ICE Custody September 7, 2024, according to the Detainee Death Report ICE published: https://www.ice.gov/doclib/foia/reports/ddrBrendyYohanaBamacaZacarias.pdf. 

Due to the increasing number of FOIA requests received by this office, we may encounter some delay in processing your request. Per Section 5.5(a) of the DHS FOIA regulations, 6 C.F.R. Part 5, ICE processes FOIA requests according to their order of receipt. Although ICE’s goal is to respond within 20 business days of receipt of your request, the FOIA does permit a 10-day extension of this time period. As your request seeks numerous documents that will necessitate a thorough and wide-ranging search, ICE will invoke a 10-day extension for your request, as allowed by Title 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(B). If you’re able to narrow the scope of your request please contact our office. Narrowing the scope may speed up the search process. We will make every effort to comply with your request in a timely manner. 

Your request for expedited treatment is hereby denied. 

Under the DHS FOIA regulations, expedited processing of a FOIA request is warranted if the request involves “circumstances in which the lack of expedited treatment could reasonably be expected to pose an imminent threat to the life or physical safety of an individual,” 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(1)(i), or “an urgency to inform the public about an actual or alleged federal government activity, if made by a person primarily engaged in disseminating information,” 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(l)(ii).  Requesters seeking expedited processing must submit a statement explaining in detail the basis for the request, and that statement must be certified by the requester to be true and correct.  6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(3). 

Your request for expedited processing is denied because you do not qualify for either category under 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(1).  You failed to demonstrate a particular urgency to inform the public about the government activity involved in the request beyond the public’s right to know about government activity generally.  Your letter was conclusory in nature and did not present any facts to justify a grant of expedited processing under the applicable standards. 

ICE has queried the appropriate program offices within ICE for responsive records. If any responsive records are located, they will be reviewed for determination of releasability. Please be assured that one of the processors in our office will respond to your request as expeditiously as possible. We appreciate your patience as we proceed with your request. 

If you have any questions please contact FOIA Public Liaison Daniel Edgington, at (866) 633-1182 or 500 12th St, SW Stop 5009 Washington, DC 20536-5009. Additionally, you have a right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974.  You may contact OGIS as follows:  Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448. 

Your request has been assigned reference number 2025-ICFO-25063. Please use this number in future correspondence. 

Sincerely, 

ICE FOIA Office 
Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Freedom of Information Act Office 
500 12th Street, S.W., Stop 5009 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5009
